ï»¿Execution Version Dated January 9, 2015 COLLABORATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global Ir frastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is en ered into on January 9, 2015 between: (1) THE BANK OF TOKYO MITh4UBISHI UFJ, LTD, herein represented by its Deputy Presiden 1 a headquartered at 2-7-1, Marunouchi, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, Japan ("BTMU"); and (2) THE WORLD BANK GROUF, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND D EVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPME ir ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, USA, Ih, INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylvanie Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("MIGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC: (4: 3, USA (the "World Bank Grou 3") (each a "Party" and together, the "Parties"). Preamble (A) There is broad international recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Interm ti:- al Organizations (lOs), the G77 and the private sector represented by the B20 that investing in e infrastructure of Emerging IVarkets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to e :l 2 d access to basic services anc raise living standards for all, and to meet global economic c ri,i,, h targets. (B) Meeting this need presents a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on e: :i!:t ig sources of infrastructure fina ice-particularly in the public sector-a redoubled and coord nal, d effort is needed to mobilize p ivate sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of robl.st pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects and I i: is understood to be the greates: barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investmer t (D) Governments, development finance institutions, donors, and private investors share an inte ES !n developing the market for pr vate infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand s d:i n the numbers of structurally sound and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual emer :ler e of EMDE infrastructure as a recognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range of I r in te investors that actively partic pate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals will l n: fit from collective action betwe an this range of entities-to leverage resources and knowle( cle to find solutions to complex i ifrastructure financing challenges that no single institution co. Id achieve alone. (E) In support of these goals, thE Parties propose the establishment of a Global Infrastructure F 3:: I ty Partnership Program ("GIF") The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at leveragil i . le efforts of the wide range of i istitutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastructui :v th the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project prepa Eli: 1, structuring, and risk mitigati )n for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, t C EF aims to complement existinq and proposed services and initiatives currently supported !i : ie Parties and other prospective GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prepar iw II- structured, infrastructure prcjects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for accessii i( : ie expertise of the Parties and other GIF partners, in combination with guidance from prosra::1ie private sector financiers into project structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater le) i= rer je of official resources in the fe ce of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particular fo a le and complex projects with th a potential to attract significant private capital. (F) The Parties are now interested in collaborating in developing the Global Infrastructure I Ec ty Partnership Program, togeth)r with other partners. 2
ï»¿Execution Version Accordingly, the Parties have come to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure Facili y Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended io be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set oul ii Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Fo indational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the GIF Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their collabc n it )n, they are of an indicative natu e and will continue to be developed amongst the Parties and 0, h other potential partners until he GIF is formally established. The final version of these objec i and principles will be agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected in the agreement establishing the GIF. 1.2 The Parties intend tc work together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to fLrther enhance their coordination, in particular by developing th :3, with a view to formally establ shing the program by June 2015. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the fore oing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to continue to collaborate in developing the GIF, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of collaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the i oles, rights, and responsibilities associated with each category b. Governance arrangements of the GIF; c. Operational policies ipplicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activities and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to proje( I: selection criteria and coordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of collaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, includil c, sharing best practice and experience with regard to project preparation, through the ko of knowledge platforms for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finali::ing the design of the GIF, the multilateral development banks Isl Ad in Annex 2 will be invited o participate as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF de:; iqn is finalized, additional collabo ative efforts are required to develop the operational details i0 I ie GIF, at all times complementing existing efforts and facilities and building upon the ! hal d knowledge and experience of the Parties in this area. This includes determining the I a , of coordination between the P arties and project origination process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration A-rangement is not a legally binding agreement or commitment I t a Parties to enter into or provic e support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisi:)ns of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their common understanding and intentiom only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose an e al obligations or liabilities on ary Party. 3.2 This Collaboration A -rangement is valid and effective for a period of one year from h1e, date thereof, unless superseJed at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Parties expect t iat this document and information with respect to the collabora i, activities contemplated herein will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' respective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult with 2:1: 1 3
ï»¿Execution Version other concerning the manner and form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's support regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arranc ement will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciatior cr other modification of any of ti e privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of the Parties under their constituer t documents, international conventions and any applicable law i In witness whereof, each of the Par ies has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be executed i i two (2) counterparts of equal content and form by a duly authorized representative of each Party as : tI e date first set forth above. 4
ï»¿Execution Version THE BANK OF TOKYO MITSUBISH UFJ, LTD By: TAKASHI MORIMURA DEPUTY PRESIDENT 5
ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, compr sing the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION IN 1) DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION and the IU ILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY By: BERTRAND BADRE MANAGING DIRECT AN ) WBG CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER 6
ï»¿Execution Version Annex I Prelirilinary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the 1F is to promote private sector investment in infrastructure prc E'c: in emerging markets and developing economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparatiol, provision of appropriate risk r litigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commercial r rd institutional investor engagement in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex public-private partnerships and projects with potential for commerc a viability which require project preparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastruc u E financing solutions that no single institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF aims to create a global platform to provide financial and coordil ili: l resources in collaboration with the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of the Alil range of donor and developn ent finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastructure, with the input and ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engagerneni c:). d stretch from upstream suppo t on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to dowr stream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and risk mitigation/credit enhancemei it. 1.3 Over the longer term by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structured infrastructure projects, the G F can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset class attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking lc,ng-t:!i ni assets in faster growing ecor omies, but which until now have been presented only limited infrastructure investment oprortunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profiles 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to ooerate according to the following core principles, to be finalizec 1 r n agreement among GIF partn irs: (i) Leveraging the private sector-specializing in project financing modalities thE 2. I draw together cc mparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing public goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly those infrastructure projects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting sustainability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to bE 3 practice standar Is for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, complementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizing tec ha I al and financial resources of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, multi e to al development institutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in an innovative and flexible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve greater leverage and adiress the complex infrastructure financing challenges that are beyond the reso irces of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected to involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in th development and implementation of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF par:riei 3 are expected to fall into one or more of the following categories: 7
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partners-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF will :' considered FundIng Partners. (ii) Technical Partnkbrs-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice and support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-funded activities and/or F rovision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity suppori instruments. (iii) Advisory Partne rs-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial and/or institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, sove'eign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as well;-. other multilateral or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure pro ects, to be invited into discussions related to project preparatic n, optimal approaches to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, with a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial and/or institutional investment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Cc uncil is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic programming management and use of funcs, and development of operational policies and procedures; an : hold the GIF Management Ur it (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility's objectives and principles, witl i advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The composil cin )f the Governing Council will be agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is propos ::H I comprise representatives of Funding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Council comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing Direc cr and Chief Financial Officer of the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facilita E coordination of GIF activities and support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve a:: sounding board, providing gu dance and support for GIF Management, and in particular witV view to ensuring suitability of projects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be admi iistered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicated e: established for this purpose (:he GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will fun :t cl as a coordinating body as projects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then move toward technical support and financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead indi, i It l projects. 4.2 GIF activity implementation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical Partner institutions, coordinated by tte GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governmeni: according to specific project iequirements and the project origination processes. Compositi :r the implementation teams may vary according to the need of individual projects and govern r er ts. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection criteria and processes could be developed to reflect the followi c0 principles: (i) Development Impact-projects that support the development goals of the GIF partner institutiot is; (ii) Alignment-pro ects that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country priorities a id strategies; (iii) Complexity-pr)jects that require multiple parties to come together to provide structuring, arrar ging and financial support, and/or projects which require a blei c financial instrum Dnts; and 8
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic Impac -projects that have significant potential to achieve financial v :yil y, leverage public funds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors-s .i:h as through Public-Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-while still meeting government's se vice delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrastricture investments that have global public good characteristics ;Uh as climate friendly-project; that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provision if infrastructure services; and ti ade enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconneci v t, and trade. 5.2 The scope of suppc rt provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, with E vie v to complementing the resour:es and support already available from partner entities and oth i funding mechanisms. During the GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following acti ril ic;, corresponding to major proje :t development stages: (i) Project definition and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; project definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility scre :i irI and legal, regulatory, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparati:)n and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and P 3P structuring; (iii) Transaction support and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, and design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arrang ng and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financin .) packages from E range of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies-including in particular the management of environmental and s:)iJ impacts and risks, and transparency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastru tui projects in supporting sustainable, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial, reputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supportec operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements ft ir external implementing entities under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an approach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards and :A h - standards and policies, and levelop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for GIF Technical Partners who are lxpected to function as implementing entities for GIF activities. 9

The operational details for the GIF will at all times complement the E,<:; 1I efforts and facilities of these MDEs, which include but are not limited to the infrastructure :m -ct preparation resources and initiatives listed below: a. African Development Bank (AfDB) - NEPAD Infrastructure Project Preparation tc ity (NEPAD-IPPF) as well as the project development business segment of Africa, C : id various support effo ts for Africa-focused PPFs; b. Asian Development Bank (ADB) - Office of Public-Private Partnership and its pr( rio ed Asia Pacific Project Preparation Facility ('AP3F') as well as several dedicated r) ( lal PPFs; c. European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) - Legal Tr, ni on Programme, and the proposed EBRD Infrastructure Project Preparation Facility ('IF F F d. European Investmont Bank (EIB) - European PPP Expertise Centre (EPEC); e. Inter-American De,relopment Bank (IADB) - 'InfraFund' project preparation facilil , f. Islamic Development Bank (IsDB) - Arab Financing Facility for Infrastructure Te:: in -al Assistance Facility 'AFFI TAF), co-managed with the International Finance Corr:) E eon (IFC); and g. World Bank Grou3 (WBG) comprising the International Bank for Reconstructi:n ind Development (IBRD), the International Development Association (IDA), the Inten E i: nal Finance Corporationi (IFC), and the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MK"1! 10
